channel.title: DNS Anycast Frontends on deSEC Status

item.title: [Resolved] Delayed replication
item.description: Due to an internal network issue, new or modified DNS records are currently not being replicated within our network. DNS resolution is not impacted, but frontend machines are serving DNS data from 6:15pm UTC. This is an internal issue; no attack has occurred. The issue is expected to be resolved around 8pm UTC today.

item.title: [Resolved] Ongoing performance issues
item.description: Since January 20, 2023, our DNS platform service has repeatedly been targeted by DDoS attacks, due to which our servers did not manage to respond to all requests. Attacks usually take around 15 minutes, during which our infrastructure is hit with around 120,000 queries per second. Over the next couple of days, we will upgrade our infrastructure to handle the increased load spikes. We apologize for any intermittent issues clients may be experiencing until the upgrade is completed.
item.content:
Since January 20, 2023, our DNS platform service has repeatedly been targeted by DDoS attacks, due to which our servers did not manage to respond to all requests. Attacks usually take around 15 minutes, during which our infrastructure is hit with around 120,000 queries per second.

Over the next couple of days, we will upgrade our infrastructure to handle the increased load spikes. We apologize for any intermittent issues clients may be experiencing until the upgrade is completed. Thank you for your patience!

(Is there any good in it? – If you will, yes: being targeted for DDoS speaks to the maturity of the platform. It is true for all DNS providers that the day of DoS arrives eventually. We’ll do out best to grow beyond it.)

item.title: [Resolved] DDoS attack
item.description: DNS frontends are currently experiencing extraordinary load due to an ongoing DDoS attack. We will update this notice once the problem has been resolved. As this is not the first incident, we will deploy more resources throughout the upcoming weeks, leading to a significant increase of the number of global server locations and their capabilities to cope with high load. We hope that this will prevent further attacks from succeeding.

item.title: [Resolved] DNSSEC Problems due to Replication Issue
item.description: deSEC DNS operations experienced a partial service disruption. The issue was caused by incomplete replication of zones after their DNSSEC signatures had been renewed, leading to DNSSEC validation failures for certain DNS queries. Impact No data was lost or compromised: our services were not under attack, nor did a physical failure occur. Signatures on domains that had not been updated since May 28, 2020, were not correctly refreshed. As a consequence, DNSSEC-aware clients or resolvers rejected those expired signatures.
item.content:
deSEC DNS operations experienced a partial service disruption. The issue was caused by incomplete replication of zones after their DNSSEC signatures had been renewed, leading to DNSSEC validation failures for certain DNS queries.

Impact

No data was lost or compromised: our services were not under attack, nor did a physical failure occur.

Signatures on domains that had not been updated since May 28, 2020, were not correctly refreshed. As a consequence, DNSSEC-aware clients or resolvers rejected those expired signatures. Domains whose contents had been updated more recently were provisioned correctly on the frontend DNS servers.

DNS clients or resolvers that do not perform DNSSEC validation were not affected and were able to query all domains at any time.

Details

You can find more information in our forum.
